articles.title: Predictions
articles.summary: This document outlines the astronomical club's calendar of events for November and December 1978, featuring various star parties, general meetings, and board meetings with specific dates and locations. It also lists several members' birthdays and includes a section of humorous quotes from club members, along with an editor's note about future quote inclusion.

articles.title: Personal Glimpses: Penny Pinschmidt, Editor
articles.summary: This article provides a personal glimpse into Penny Pinschmidt, a well-known editor among SJAA astronomers. She developed an interest in astronomy in 1976, became a SJAA member, and now enjoys observing, combining astronomy with her passions for writing and photography. Currently, she is a student at West Valley College, pursuing a diverse range of subjects, including two astronomy classes.

articles.title: SECRETARY'S LIBRARY     Cathy Pinheiro
articles.summary: Cathy Pinheiro provides an update from the Secretary's Library, reminding club members that its collection of books, magazines, and pamphlets is available for checkout. The column, returning after a month's absence, lists several titles including astronomy, space, and general interest topics.

articles.title: By Denni Medlock
articles.summary: This article details a lively Halloween costume party and birthday celebration for several members of an astronomy club, filled with humorous anecdotes and costume descriptions. It also includes reports from a general meeting, discussing a comet award, film photography techniques, and educational films, alongside accounts of various star parties, noting travel mishaps and observing conditions. The piece concludes with a brief technical discussion on the speed of gravity and a classified ad.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: In the preceding two months, amateur astronomers discovered five comets. However, only one of these five remains within observing reach, as three have moved below the southern horizon and another is too faint to be seen.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Haneda-Campos (1978j).
articles.summary: Periodic Comet Haneda-Campos (1978j), discovered on September 1st, is currently at magnitude 13 in the constellation Fornax. The comet is moving further from both Earth and the Sun, causing it to steadily become fainter.

articles.title: Comet Machholz (1978i).
articles.summary: Comet Machholz (1978i) was observed on Oct. 11 at -47 degrees with a magnitude of 10.5. The comet is currently moving away from both the Sun and Earth, heading south, making it no longer visible from the observer's location. Orbital computations suggest its next return could be in 200 to 1,000 years.

articles.title: Comet Seargent (1978m).
articles.summary: Comet Seargent (1978m), a magnitude 5 object, was discovered on October 1st by David Seargent in New South Wales. It was located 35 degrees south of the sun and is moving further south. Its future visibility from Earth is uncertain, with a possibility of being seen in a few months.

articles.title: Comet Fujikawa (1978n).
articles.summary: Comet Fujikawa (1978n) was discovered on October 9 as an 11 magnitude object by Shigehisa Fujikawa, marking his third discovery. The comet is moving out of the sun's rays and is projected to travel west then north in the morning sky within the constellation Leo, with an ephemeris to follow.

articles.title: Comet Bradfield (1978o).
articles.summary: Comet Bradfield (1978o) was discovered on October 10th as an 8th magnitude object visible low in the morning sky. It is predicted to move south, then loop west and north, potentially becoming visible again at magnitude 11 in early November from the low south. This discovery marks William Bradfield's eighth comet find in eight years.

articles.title: Comet Ashbrook-Jackson (1977g).
articles.summary: This article provides details and an ephemeris for Comet Ashbrook-Jackson (1977g), described as a 12th magnitude object in Pisces, approximately 1 arcminute across. It also highlights a recent surge in comet discoveries by amateur astronomers, noting their common characteristics (south of the ecliptic, morning sky, post-perihelion) without explaining the trend. Additional ephemerides for other comets are also included for observer reference.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: This document, titled "Rattley Rattles," provides detailed observational notes and descriptions for a selection of deep-sky objects, primarily galaxies and one open cluster, found on Chart II of the Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens. It offers practical viewing tips for amateur astronomers, including recommended powers and sky conditions, along with key characteristics like brightness, size, shape, and membership in the Local Group of galaxies.

articles.title: Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects - Chart II, continued
articles.summary: This article, part of the "Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects - Chart II" series, serves as an observational guide for amateur astronomers. It meticulously details various deep-sky objects, including galaxies, open clusters, and planetary nebulae, providing their celestial coordinates, types, magnitudes, and essential viewing recommendations. Each entry offers practical advice on power settings, sky conditions, and notable features to enhance the observing experience.

articles.title: Jim Van Nuland
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland led a perplexing graze expedition near Kerman, California, meticulously setting up observation stations that puzzled local residents. A diverse group of observers gathered, enjoying excellent night sky conditions before successfully conducting the lunar graze event, which yielded varied results reported across multiple stations. Following discussions of their findings, participants concluded the expedition, with Jim and Gerry eventually driving home after a long but successful outing.

articles.title: New members to add to the list published in September
articles.summary: This document presents a list of new members to be added to an existing membership roster that was published in September. It includes four new members with their names, addresses, cities, zip codes, and some phone numbers, indicating an update to an organization's member directory.

articles.title: Bulletin Subscribers
articles.summary: This document lists current bulletin subscribers with their names, addresses, and phone numbers. It also includes an update for a subscriber's change of address, indicating it serves as a contact roster for an organization's members.

articles.title: Profile Chart on The September 24 Lunar Graze Occultation
articles.summary: This document presents a profile chart summarizing data from an expedition observing the September 24 Lunar Graze Occultation, noting the exaggerated vertical scale and issues like poor seeing and equipment malfunctions that affected event timing. Despite challenges, the report package is slated for analysis by Dr. Dunham and subsequent forwarding to the Nautical Almanac Office at the Royal Greenwich Observatory. The corrected predicted profile is still pending for comparison.

articles.title: Excerpts from The First Three Minutes by Steven Weinberg submitted by Allan Meyer
articles.summary: This article provides excerpts from Steven Weinberg's "The First Three Minutes," describing the universe at its "first frame" when its temperature was 100 million Kelvin. At this point, the universe was in a state of nearly perfect thermal equilibrium, filled with an undifferentiated soup of matter and radiation, and the text discusses its potential size during this extremely early period of cosmic evolution.

articles.title: Blurbs
articles.summary: This bulletin blurb from the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) confirms a new official return address stamp and addresses the editor's oversight regarding the 'Question of the Month,' which will be repeated. It also acknowledges cartoon submissions for the bulletin, praises members for their contributions, and announces an upcoming equipment night on November 18th.

articles.title: Red Spot Recovered by Jim Van Nuland
articles.summary: Astronomer Jim Van Nuland successfully recovered the Great Red Spot of Jupiter on October 13, performing astronomical detective work. The Jovian Jewel was found hidden within the south equatorial belt, disguised by gray clouds, but became visible with a 3" Newtonian telescope under excellent seeing conditions. There is hope that the spot will soon regain its prominent visibility for all observers.

articles.title: Lower Limits, 9.5h; 7.0h Upper Limits, 13.5h, 10.2h With Randomizing
articles.summary: This document appears to be a log or record of observations related to the 'Great Red Spot on Jeridian Disk' (likely Jupiter's Great Red Spot). It lists numerous dates and times, possibly indicating observation windows or calculated limits. The title refers to 'Lower Limits' and 'Upper Limits' in hours, suggesting a measurement or prediction of visibility or event duration, potentially with randomized elements.
